section.title: Introduction to Determinants
section.introduction: The determinant is a number associated with a matrix, which provides information about its invertibility, as well as information about its associated linear transformation. More precisely, the determinant in an operation (or function) on a matrix, i.e. whose input is a matrix, and output is a real number.
section.subsection:
Determinants
There are a few motivations for the determinant. One is as a criterion for invertibility of a matrix, which recall is equivalent to a corresponding system of equations having a unique solution. In particular, a matrix A is invertible if and only if the system of equations A\vec{x} = \vec{b} has a unique solution.
First, consider the most basic case, of a 1 \times 1 matrix, of the form A = \begin{bmatrix} a \end{bmatrix}, which corresponds to the coefficient matrix of the single-equation system,
ax = b
Or, in matrix form,
\begin{bmatrix} a \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} b \end{bmatrix}
The inverse of A is the matrix A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{a} \end{bmatrix}, provided that a \neq 0. Equivalently, the unique solution to the system is x = \frac{b}{a}, again provided that a \neq 0.
In general, we will define the determinant in such a way so that a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is non-zero. In this way, we define the determinant of a 1 \times 1 matrix as the entry itself.
For a 1 \times 1 matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} a \end{bmatrix}, the determinant of A is \det{A} = a.
For a 2 \times 2 matrix, of the form,
A = \begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix}
which corresponds to the system,
a x_1 + b x_2 \amp = y_1 c x_1 + d x_2 \amp = y_2
Recall that the matrix A is invertible if and only if \Delta = ad - bc \neq 0. Equivalently, recall that the system has a unique solution,
x_1 = \frac{1}{\Delta}(d y_1 - b y_2) \qquad x_2 = \frac{1}{\Delta}(ay_2 - cy_1)
provided that \Delta = ad - bc \neq 0. This difference of the products of the diagonals we will define as the determinant of a 2 \times 2 matrix.
For a 2 \times 2 matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix}, the determinant of A, \det{A}, is defined by,
\det{A} = ad - bc
Note that we are using functional notation \det{A} for the determinant of A, treating \det as a function with argument A. When writing the matrix explcitly, we could write,
\det{\begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix}} = ad - bc
Determinants are also denoted with vertical bars, as
\begin{vmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{vmatrix} = ad - bc
Intuitively, this can be thought of in some sense as a magnitude of the matrix, as we will see later.

3 \times 3 Determinants and Larger
For 3 \times 3 matrices and larger, evaluating determinants is more complex. Let A be a 3 \times 3 matrix,
A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} \amp a_{12} \amp a_{13} \\ a_{21} \amp a_{22} \amp a_{23} \\ a_{31} \amp a_{32} \amp a_{33} \end{bmatrix}
Similarly, we want to define the determinant as a number depending on the entries of the matrix, which is equal to zero precisely when the matrix is not invertible.
